Lars Clausen writes:
> Has anyone studied how well the compression in the ARC file works
> compared to how well a file system or the hardware can compress?  IMHO,
> leaving the compression to the underlying layers would lessen the risk
> of the file itself becoming unreadable.  Hardware compression stays with
> the hardware, in-format compression can (and does) confuse people.  

Short answer: I haven't compared with hardware compression.

But:

The Flate algorithm (used by GZIP) does really well on text,
especially text with lots of redundancies. The algorithm is well
defined (RFCs 1950 and 1951) and widely accepted. Implementations
exist for pretty much every current platform, and will continue to be
created, I expect.

Hardware compression's problem, IMHO, is the fact that the compression
lives on the hardware. If you move the file to a different disk or
backup to tape or DVD-R or whatever you loose the compression, and
will probably end up having to recompress the ARC files anyway.

Handling GZIP appears to be complicated by Java, not by the algorithms
themselves: the JNI bindings to the libz library make the low-level
manipulation of the GZIP streams difficult. Doing this from C++ was
much easier.

    -tree
